text: When I go in and directly am involved with a company on the acquisition side, I am thinking about my hypotheses on the acquisition pretty early on, because if I go into it and I have no idea how we'll acquire those customers, I'm not real confident I'll figure it out when I'm there.
speaker: Sean Ellis
context: Lenny asks Sean about his approach to helping companies figure out growth strategy. Sean explains that even though he focuses on activation and onboarding first, he still develops early hypotheses about customer acquisition channels before taking on a project. He wants to have 2-3 viable acquisition ideas going in, knowing he'll likely discover more, so that at least one channel will work profitably.
text_ko: 제가 직접 고객 확보(acquisition) 쪽으로 회사에 들어가서 관여할 때는, 고객 확보에 대한 가설을 꽤 일찍부터 세워요. 왜냐하면 들어가서 그 고객들을 어떻게 확보할지 전혀 감이 없다면, 현장에서 가서 그걸 알아낼 수 있을 거라는 확신이 별로 안 들거든요.
text_zh: 当我直接参与一家公司的收购时，我会很早就开始思考我对这次收购的假设，因为如果我进去的时候对怎么获取那些客户一点头绪都没有，我可不敢保证到时候能想出办法来。
text_es: Cuando me meto de lleno y me involucro directamente con una empresa en el tema de adquisición, desde muy temprano ya estoy pensando en mis hipótesis sobre cómo vamos a captar clientes, porque si entro sin tener ni idea de cómo vamos a conseguir esos clientes, la verdad es que no me da mucha confianza que lo vaya a resolver una vez que ya esté ahí metido.

text: Customer acquisition is so hard that if you're not really efficient at converting and retaining and monetizing people, you're going to really struggle on the customer acquisition side.
speaker: Sean Ellis
context: Sean explains his prioritization approach to growth - focusing first on activation, then engagement and referrals, then revenue optimization, and only lastly on customer acquisition. He argues that in today's competitive environment, companies must be extremely efficient at converting, retaining, and monetizing customers before they can succeed at scalable customer acquisition.
text_ko: 고객 획득(customer acquisition)이 워낙 힘들어서, 전환(converting)·유지(retaining)·수익화(monetizing)을 효율적으로 못하면 고객 확보 쪽에서 진짜 고생해요.
text_zh: 获客这么难，如果你在转化、留存和变现这块做得不够好的话，那获客这边你肯定会很吃力。
text_es: Conseguir clientes nuevos es tan difícil que si no eres realmente eficiente convirtiendo, reteniendo y monetizando a la gente, te va a costar muchísimo en el lado de adquisición de clientes.

text: If you start paying attention to what your somewhat disappointed users are telling you and then you start tweaking onboarding and product based on their feedback, maybe you're going to dilute it for your must have users.
speaker: Sean Ellis
context: Lenny asks what to do when only 10% of users would be very disappointed without the product. Sean advises ignoring users who say they'd be 'somewhat disappointed' because they view the product as nice-to-have. He warns that optimizing for these users might make the product good for everyone but great for no one, potentially weakening its value for the core must-have users.
text_ko: 다소 실망한 사용자들이 하는 말에 귀 기울여 그 피드백을 바탕으로 온보딩(onboarding)과 제품을 조금씩 손봐서 맞추기 시작하면, 오히려 핵심 사용자들(must-have users)에게는 제품의 강점이 희석될 수 있어요.
text_zh: 如果你开始关注那些有点失望的用户的反馈，然后根据他们的意见去调整用户引导(onboarding)和产品，可能会让你的核心用户体验变差。
text_es: Si empiezas a hacerle caso a lo que te dicen los usuarios que están medio decepcionados y luego te pones a ajustar el onboarding y el producto basándote en sus comentarios, a lo mejor vas a terminar diluyendo la experiencia para tus usuarios que realmente no pueden vivir sin tu producto.

text: I think one of the biggest challenges in an early stage startup is half the people feel like we're years from having this product ready to grow, and half the people are like, 'What are we waiting for?' Where if you can actually get people on the same page of what does product market fit look like for our business, and it's at that point that we're going to.
speaker: Sean Ellis
context: Lenny asks about how firm the 40% threshold is in the Sean Ellis test. Sean explains that having a specific target like 40% helps align teams on when to start scaling growth efforts. Without this alignment, startup teams often split between those who think the product needs years more work and those eager to start growing immediately.
vocabulary_highlights: get people on the same page
text_ko: 제 생각에 초창기 스타트업(early stage startup)에서 가장 큰 문제 중 하나는 팀의 절반은 '이 제품이 성장할 준비가 되려면 몇 년은 더 걸리겠구나'라고 느끼고, 나머지 절반은 '우린 도대체 뭘 기다리고 있는 거야?'라고 생각하는 거예요. 그런데 제품-시장 적합성(product market fit)이 우리 비즈니스에서 어떤 모습이어야 하는지 모두가 같은 페이지에 있으면, 바로 그때부터 움직이기 시작하는 거죠.
text_zh: 我觉得早期创业公司最大的挑战之一就是，一半的人觉得我们的产品离能够规模化还有好几年，另一半的人就说"我们还在等什么？"这时候如果你能让大家对什么叫产品市场契合度(product market fit)达成共识，明确到了那个点我们就要开始行动。
text_es: Creo que uno de los mayores retos en una startup que está empezando es que la mitad del equipo siente que nos faltan años para tener el producto listo para crecer, y la otra mitad está como "¿qué estamos esperando?" Entonces, si logras que toda la gente esté en la misma página sobre cómo se ve el product market fit para nuestro negocio, ahí es cuando vamos a...

text: Even when I first moved to Silicon Valley, I remember the conversations back at LogMeIn in the mid 2000s of kind of like, 'When do we step on the gas? What is the combination of factors that need to be in place before we start pouring fuel on the early fire?'
speaker: Sean Ellis
context: Sean continues explaining why having a clear product-market fit threshold is important for startup teams. He shares how even before the term 'product-market fit' existed, his team at LogMeIn in the mid-2000s struggled with the same fundamental question of when exactly to start aggressively scaling their growth efforts.
vocabulary_highlights: pouring fuel on the early fire
text_ko: 실리콘밸리(Silicon Valley)로 처음 왔을 때도, 2000년대 중반 LogMeIn에서 나눴던 대화가 기억나요. 대충 이런 얘기였어요: "언제 엑셀을 밟아야 할까요? 초기 불씨에 연료를 더 붓기 전에 어떤 요소들이 갖춰져야 할까요?"
text_zh: 我记得2000年代中期刚到硅谷的时候，我们在LogMeIn内部经常讨论这样的问题："什么时候该全力冲刺？需要哪些条件都到位了，我们才能开始给这个刚起步的项目大力投入资源？"
text_es: Incluso cuando me mudé por primera vez a Silicon Valley, recuerdo las conversaciones que teníamos en LogMeIn a mediados de los 2000, algo así como: '¿Cuándo le metemos el acelerador a fondo? ¿Qué combinación de factores tiene que estar en su lugar antes de echarle más leña al fuego inicial?'

text: I think basically for each business it's just thinking about what's unique for that business that is going to open up channel opportunities and everyone's going to be a little bit, I think jaded from whatever the last thing that worked really well.
speaker: Sean Ellis
context: Lenny asks how to help businesses figure out which growth channel to focus on - whether paid acquisition, SEO, sales, or virality. Sean explains that each business has unique characteristics that make certain channels more viable, and warns that people often get biased by their previous successful experiences and try to apply the same approach to different businesses.
text_ko: 제 생각엔 기본적으로 각 비즈니스는 자기만의 고유한 게 뭔지 생각해서 그걸로 채널 기회(channel opportunities)를 만들어내는 게 중요해요. 그리고 사람들은 이전에 효과가 좋았던 것 때문에 다들 좀 식상해져 있을 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得基本上每个生意都要想想，自己有什么独特的地方能开拓新的渠道机会，而且大家对之前那些很成功的做法多少都会有点审美疲劳。
text_es: Mira, creo que básicamente para cada negocio se trata de pensar qué es lo único de ese negocio que va a abrir oportunidades de canal, y todo el mundo va a estar un poco escamado por lo último que funcionó realmente bien.
